item.description:
How the Common Law courts, which grew out of English and Scottish anarchy, embodied Rand's
ideal state. Galt's Gulch needed no constitution -- all it needed was Judge Narragansett, but neither Rand
nor Judge Narragansett realized it when at the end of Atlas Shrugged he set out to write a new constitution
for the Gulch. The Founding Fathers' vision of a constitutional republic, although vastly different in
practice from its current embodiment, directly led to the current statist quagmire. Because the Founding
Fathers' vision is more appealing than the current modern state, Rand and libertarians tend to uphold
the Founding Fathers' vision with an uncritical eye -- it is, in theory, better than the modern state,
and so has achieved a sometimes undeserved place of reverence. But Rand and libertarians overlook a much
better, third alternative: the Common Law courts in an otherwise anarchic state. Early English Common Law
courts did exactly what Rand required: created a rational government limited to defending life, liberty, and property,
without venturing into paternalist policymaking.
